rationales.achievement: Mei-Lin internalizes achievement pressure through her daughter's test score ('only 18?'), showing concern for performance standards even while outwardly praising her daughter.
rationales.conformity: She avoided conflict by changing the subject to 'the soup being too salty' rather than confronting her mother-in-law's criticism, prioritizing harmony over defending her daughter.
rationales.tradition: She defers to her mother-in-law's authority and cultural norms around comparison ('I know she means well. I know comparison is how she shows she cares'), accepting the elder's behavior.
rationales.benevolence: Despite her internal conflict, she protected her daughter by putting the test 'on the fridge with a magnet' and telling her she was proud, prioritizing her child's wellbeing.

rationales.achievement: Registered daughter for enrichment center ('an investment, not an expense'), actively pursuing educational advancement for her child.
rationales.security: Despite making the investment, she 'keep[s] opening the banking app to look at the balance,' showing anxiety about financial stability and security.
rationales.benevolence: The $800/month expense for enrichment is a sacrifice for her daughter's benefit, demonstrating investment in close family welfare.

rationales.self_direction: She surrenders her own needs entirely: 'I'm running on four hours of sleep' while managing all responsibilities, not asserting her need for help from her husband.
rationales.hedonism: Sacrificing personal comfort and wellbeing (sleep, self-care) for family duties: 'I haven't even brushed my teeth yet.'
rationales.achievement: Continues to pursue phonics practice because daughter is 'a bit behind the others,' maintaining focus on performance benchmarks despite exhaustion.
rationales.conformity: She doesn't wake her husband because 'he has that big presentation tomorrow,' prioritizing his work expectations and social role over her own needs.
rationales.benevolence: Up at 2am 'holding him while he cries,' she prioritizes comforting her son during nightmares despite personal exhaustion.

rationales.self_direction: She lied about 'exploring options' for tuition rather than expressing her authentic budget-conscious approach, surrendering autonomy to social pressure.
rationales.achievement: Extensive focus on tracking progress ('my notebook, the one I keep for tracking both kids' progress'), ordering 'three new comprehension workbooks' with express delivery.
rationales.security: Detailed financial anxiety despite objective stability: 'eight months becomes four,' quoting her mother's wisdom about saving 'for nine winters.'
rationales.conformity: Lied to another mother about tuition to avoid social judgment, 'didn't want to admit we only do the one enrichment class.'
rationales.tradition: Invokes her mother's traditional wisdom ('save for nine winters') as guiding principle, finding meaning in inherited cultural values about financial prudence.
rationales.benevolence: Diligently attended parent-teacher conference, took notes, and ordered resources to support daughter's reading comprehension needs.

rationales.conformity: Participated in the family gathering's comparison culture ('All the cousins comparing which schools their kids got into') rather than pushing back or withdrawing.
rationales.benevolence: Self-critical recognition that she failed her daughter: 'I should have pulled her into the conversation. I should have let her be a child,' showing she neglected her daughter's emotional needs.

rationales.achievement: Defended the third workbook despite husband's concern that daughter 'looked tired,' prioritizing achievement goals over comfort.
rationales.power: Asserted control over parenting decisions: 'I'm the one here every day, I see what she needs,' claiming authority and shutting down husband's input.
rationales.benevolence: Snapped at her husband and dismissed his concern for their daughter's wellbeing, prioritizing her agenda over family harmony and her daughter's tiredness.

rationales.self_direction: Made an autonomous choice to break from her usual patterns when daughter asked 'if we could just play today. No workbooks, no practice. Just play. And I said yes.'
rationales.hedonism: Prioritized enjoyment and present pleasure: 'We built a blanket fort and read picture books inside it... She laughed so hard at the silly voices.'
rationales.achievement: Deliberately stepped away from achievement tracking: 'For two hours I forgot about enrichment schedules and comprehension scores,' questioning if she's 'measuring the right things.'
rationales.benevolence: Responded to her daughter's emotional needs, resulting in 'Mama, today was the best day,' prioritizing connection and her child's happiness over productivity.
